name: Divekick
description: Divekick is the world’s first two-button fighting game. It distills the essence of the fighting game genre into just two buttons with no d-pad directional movement. Includes two extra playable characters: Fencer from Nidhogg and Johnny Gat from Saints Row!
minimum_requirements: OS: Vista or later Processor: Intel or AMD Dual Core Processor Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: DirectX 10 / DirectX 11 compliant video card DirectX: Version 10 Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 2 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX 10 compliant Additional Notes: OS needs to be updated to have the DirectX 11 Runtime libraries

reviews.review_text: Dive.  Or kick.  Either way you're going to choke, you colossal fraud.

It’s all about that one moment. Everyone who’s ever played or watched a fighting game knows it. It’s the final round, both players have a slither of health left and the next move is pivotal; the difference between success and failure, win or lose. Whether it’s playing against a friend, competing in an online ranked match or watching one of the many tournament streams of the fighting game community, everyone knows that one moment. It’s the veritable height of tension, excitement, elation and anguish. Divekick is that one moment distilled into an entire game. Each round of every single fight captures the thrill of those final few seconds in a tightly-contested bout; the moment that entices newcomers to the genre and sends diehard fans into mass hysteria. And it’s all accomplished with only two buttons.  What started out as a simple concept featuring two near-mechanically identical characters and a staple move of 2D fighting games, has now evolved to feature a roster of thirteen that surprises with its hidden depth. It’s odd to say that a game with only two buttons has any intricacy, but therein lies Divekick’s beauty. With one button to jump and one to kick it’s easily accessible for newcomers to the genre. Rounds are a quick twenty seconds and each fight’s nine possible rounds will end after one single hit. It’s the fighting game condensed to its purest form, sans any barrier to entry and welcoming to those dumbfounded and put off by the commitment required to learn the inner workings of the genres best. It’s a test of reads and reactions, of tactically positioning yourself based on your character’s idiosyncrasies and those of your opponent.  You simply jump and divekick, launching through the air to knock your opponent down in their stride.The characters of Dive and Kick showcase this concept at its base level, adopting the roles of Ken and Ryu (even if they are parodies of Yun and Yang) in Divekick’s outlandish universe with the most easy-to-grasp attacks. Positioning is determined by how high you jump and the angle of your kick. Press the kick button when your feet are on the ground and you hop backwards; kick enough and your super meter fills, how you use it depends on your fighter selection. These are simple systems and mechanics that welcome the uninitiated, removing the need to mesmerise button combos. Anyone can pick up Divekick and immediately start having fun, and it’s certainly at its best when played with friends, either locally or online.  However, there is an ever present complexity underpinning this apparent simplicity. Venture away from Dive and Kick and you’ll encounter characters with variations on the simple divekick. The Baz, for example, doesn’t defeat his opponents with his kick but with a trail of lightning that follows it. He can also pause mid-air and alter the angle of his kick, making him very effective if you can adjust to the peculiar way he deals damage. Other characters, like Jefailey, change from round to round. With each win his head begins to grow as his ego inflates, allowing you to jump higher while subsequently increasing the likelihood of suffering a critical headshot that leaves you concussed in the next round, drastically reducing the height of your jumps and the speed of your kicks. Dr Shoals, on the other hand, can perform a trajectory altering kick during her initial attack.  Each of Divekick’s thirteen characters adopt their own unique move lists, terrifically setting them apart from one another. That philosophy continues as you begin to experiment with each fighter’s singular special moves. As you build up the super meter via kicking you can either exert it by using Kick Factor (a parody of Marvel vs Capcom 3’s X-Factor that speeds up your character for a limited time) or by using your special moves. Each character has a ground move and an air move that can be activated by pressing both buttons at once provided you have enough meter. These range from the ability to temporarily float in the air to avoid dangerous situations or to set-up divekicks of your own, to a shoryuken-style Upkick and a handy duck. Though each character shares the same two buttons it quickly becomes apparent how diverse they each are, drawing an improbable amount of depth out of its simple control scheme.  Of course, this welcome complexity does contradict the notion that Divekick is incredibly easy to pick-up-and-play for newcomers to the fighting genre. There’s certainly an amount of explanation required whenever someone new picks a different character and wants to learn their many quirks, but Divekick handily subsides this somewhat with a story mode for each fighter. The AI is a tad on the easy side but these fights offer up a way to learn each character’s move list whilst unearthing their back stories via a handful of short motion comics.   Once you begin to play competitively against other people Divekick’s appeal is at its most discernible. Whether you’re playing locally with friends for a laugh or displaying your high-level skills in a ranked match, Divekick’s mechanics and use of basic fighting game concepts translate well to any environment. Some may write it off because of its simplistic control scheme and visual style but they would be missing the point. It may have slightly deviated from its original design to welcome the uninitiated to the genre – the many, many knowing references reveal a game that’s meant for the fighting game community more than anyone else – but the added depth proves welcome, even if it requires a little more understanding. Divekick is still all about that one moment, there’s just a little more nuance along the way.

I totally and completly recommend this game to anyone. Its easy to rag on the game because it has two buttons or because the characters are niche, catered towards the fighting game community, but it is so good. I am not a huge member of the FGC, but I still appreciate the tight gameplay, fun and intensity this game offers.  If you have money to spare, enjoy fighting games, or just want to support something unique and creative, pick this up. You could be more impressed than you'd expect.
Divekick is an interesting fighting game. Looks ugly, but besides that, it's fun, light but not that easy to master.

Divekick is simply a game in which you kick and dive and you actually can only use 2 buttons for that. While this makes the game pretty easy to learn, it still can be hard to master and I feel like more people hate me, because of this simple game, than because of any other fighter. It is random and can sometimes annoy you, but I really like it.
It's a deep fighting game without the execution barrier. Smooth GGPO netplay, hilarious local multiplayer. Just plain fun.
very fun and addicting to play with friends

This game is easily worth a 60$ pricetag  More technical then Skullgirls yet more advanced then a 2 button fighter. It has something for all the weeaboo's such as Mr. N or S-Kill.  If I'd recommend any fighting game currently on Steam it would have to be Divekick; comparing it to Street Fighter is a laugh! This game has a much higher skill ceiling then the latter.  All in all game is worth every penny, easy to detect all the frauds that think they know what a fighting game is.  9.75/10  *The points docked are because there is clearly 'some' room for gameplay improvement in the near future but currently the game has a solid meta-game.

'If Street Fighter is a blender, Divekick is a straight razor. If Street Fighter IV is suing someone for libel, Divekick is decapitating someone with a NASCAR. If Virtua Fighter is a bag of frozen broccoli florets, Divekick is shotgunning an entire french press of coffee. If Starcraft is a sport, Divekick is a crime scene.'

Stupidly simple yet brilliantly balanced and with a lot of depth, Divekick is a game that's equally fun to play whether you're a hardcore fighting game player or you never even saw any of the games in the genre.  Each character has different speed and angles of dives, along with two special moves that you can use to get a tactical advantage. The fights are incredibly fast! This is an instant-kill game, meaning that you win a round with only one hit. Sounds tough? It is! You need to constantly try to outsmart your opponent, baiting him and setting traps.  Divekick proves that fighting games don't need to be intimidating, nor sport hundreds of moves and combos. It's lighthearted with lots of gaming and pop culture references and fighting game in-jokes. It might not look like a work of art, but it doesn't need to, as long as it provides some good laughs and easy-to-learn-hard-to-master mechanics. Which is exactly what it does great and why I wholeheartedly recommend it!
If you can look past the sub-par graphics and the meme-infested jokes thrown throughout, Divekick is one of the most fun fighting games I've played in years.

Very simple but otherwise very tense fighting game; if there's a game to get into fighters with, it's probably this or Skullgirls. Two buttons make things easy to learn (though controlling the menu with just them can be slightly annoying), there's a fair amount of character variety, and all in all it's good (though as I mentioned, quite tense, considering the constant threat of OHK) fun.

Divekick is a modern classic that reinvents the fighting genre by trimming back to the bare bone mechanics. While it originally started as a parody of the modern fighting game, it has evolved into something greater than it's origins.  With only 2 buttons (Dive & Kick), the controls are surprisingly simple to appeal to everybody... yet has some subtities that can appeal to the more hardcore player. Battles are quick & are one-hit deals, so mastering the control & the reach of your character becomes critical for success.  If you're looking for fighting game that takes another path, you'll definitely want to give Divekick a try.
Now this right here is a game.

For a game that only requires 2 buttons, it's absolutley amazing. Do yourself a favor and buy the 2-pack for you and a friend. At first I didn't expect it to be that great, but after playing a few matches I found myself addicted to the game.
Just about the highest grade entertainment you can get for cheap almost as good as one of those ♥♥♥♥♥s you see on the block yo #thuglife
Divekick is the best two-buttion fighting game ever made.
Two buttons dive and kick simple but awesome.

Divekick is a joke, and that's the best part about it. The characters are hilarious and each one is more ridiculous than the last. The entire game is a parody of every fighting game out there and it just works. Somehow a two button fighting game is amusing and takes control, strategy, and timing. However because the game only uses two buttons, controlling your specials gets very buggy and confusing and the gameplay itself gets rather repetitive. Though there is a large roster of characters with different specials and different storylines there just isn't much the developers can do to make the game any different between characters when they are limited to two buttons. Not to mention the very slow loading screen between very quick points. Overall the gameplay is fun and local play can get very intense and I visit this game again every so often but the lack of creativity and difference in gameplay makes me feel like it's all been done. 7.5/10

Really bizarre fighting game. It's good. You only use two buttons, even in the menus. 'Kick' to either jump-kick forward (in the air) or jump back (from the ground), and 'dive' (jump) straight up. one landed kick wins a 'round' and it's best out of 9 to win. So there's a lot of starting and stopping, but there's a lot of strategy as much as there is action. Don't expect street fighter here.
You dive, and then you kick. Revolutionary. 10/10.
One buttons called dive but it jumps  0/10

This game.....OH THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME. There is only Dive and Kick no combo breakers, combos, punching, jabbing, final moves, crying, or even a ♥♥♥♥ing health system. That's right one hit K.O. NO BACKING DOWN, NO CRYING, AND NO CALLING FOR MOMMY TO CHANGE YOUR RUSTLED UP DIAPER...THIS IS ♥♥♥♥ING HYPE AS ♥♥♥♥ DIVEKICK.................................................................................. MOTHA♥♥♥♥AS

Complexity in 2 buttons. This game is so much fun. Funny story, and just alot of depth for a 2 button game i really enjoy! Even has online matchmaking ranked and unranked as well as private lobby options. It was made as a joke originally but end product is something with rich gameplay XD

pls this game is mad good  pros: - you can dive - you can kick - kicks are strong - kicks are way cooler than lame punches - street fighter aint got ♥♥♥♥ - diving makes kicking even better - there are more than 2 characters  cons: -??? -perhaps not enough kicking

If you are a fan of fighting games, and you don't own this, you're making a terrible mistake. I was hesitant to try it due to its simple concept of only having two buttons; Dive and Kick. I was under the impression that what made fighting games fun was the challenge of inputting complicated button commands to perform combos and ultras and knowing when to use them. Trying this game out on a whim, I was won over almost instantly. I don't think I've ever laughed as hard playing a fighting game as I have playing Divekick. Its simplistic input design masks a plethora of fun. Everything from funny and interesting references of fighting games and the FGC to the realization of how silly it is to be so salty over the fact that you got beat by Jefailey even though you were playing the Baz. So I'll reiterate - if you like fighting games, or even if you think you might like fighting games, pick this game up. Pick it up for yourself, and get a couple copies for your friends too, because just like every other fighting game, it's more fun with friends!

This game is awesome!!! Its an indie fighter that is totally different than any other game you'll ever play. It has characters that are based on real people who are known in the fighting game scene. Buy this game

Divekick is the perfect low barrier for entry fighting game. Anyone who has been wanting to try a fighting game and get into the genre should give this a try. I has a lot of great humor and gameplay is solid. I mean 2 buttons is all there is to it! I highly recomend Divekick if you are even a casual gamer. The quick matches and solid online play make this a must have!

Complexity in 2 buttons. This game is so much fun. Funny story, and just alot of depth for a 2 button game i really enjoy! Even has online matchmaking ranked and unranked as well as private lobby options. It was made as a joke originally but end product is something with rich gameplay XD

Its a ♥♥♥♥ simple to play comedy game. What more to say? Yes there are a number of things only the FGC will get. That said there are plenty of laughs to had if you are not a part of the FGC and more casual to fighting games. Divekick is a dumb yet very tense game at times. Some may call it a one trick pony and maybe it is but I got this game when it cost more and got more than my money's worth. Now its cheaper and that makes it even more so.
10/10 5 Stars 100 Metacritic GOTY, All Years
IT IS AMAZING IF YOU LIKE FUNNY, STUPID GAMES GET THIS BUT USE A 66% OFF COUPON WITH IT!
I don't like 1v1 fighting games but this is nice and simple. The humor is pretty good too.  Only just starting playing, I may change my feelings later.

Divekick is a fun little game that has got a great announcer. Divekciichas also made leaps and bounds by becoming a personal 1 choice on how to decide what game me and my friend decide to play with THE ULTIMATE S-KILL DIVEKCIK SHOWDOWN.
Not at all a serious game but it's still fun as hell, in my opinion.

Exactly what it says on the tin. You need to divekick to finish off your opponent (which is your only move by the way) This minimalistic 2-button affectionate-parody fighting game manages to appeal to even the new to the genre. It works simple, it's fun, it's ...DIVEKICK.   GET THIS GAME.
Dive and kick
Not enough jumping, too much diving and kicking. Pretty ok.

It's goofy and dumb as hell, but it's a blast to play. Fun for casual and core players. If anyone has any basic understanding of spacing in fighting games, that skill carries over into this game. Online plays feels really good too. Most of my matches went very well.

A hilarious 'fighting' game! There is some serious meta to this game ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°). It's also got some dank fight game memes.  Would totally recommend if you plan on playing it with a group of friends locally!

Divekick is a Streetfighter parody. Specifically, a take on how noobs typically play Streetfighter when they don't know any moves: Jump, Kick, repeat. That is the whole concept for Divekick, jumping and kicking. <-- Knowing that, don't take the game too seriously. It's not a serious fighter, it's a laugh. If you treat it as such it's sure to be a lot of fun.

UPDATED ON APRIL 23  A TIP FROM UNCLE SENSEI: BUY THIS GAME. IT'S GREAT!  And why he says that? There's only two buttons: One to jump, and another to kick. You think this makes the game easy? WRONG! I have to admit, I become very tense when playing this game; One hit and you're done for, KO! And In addition to that, you have to be fast or the timer runs out and the closer player to the middle of the arena wins.  Currently it looks like people are not playing this online anymore. However, you can buy this game to play locally with friends. ------------------------------------------------------------------ Update: If you want to get this game, get it for multiplayer. Singleplayer becomes ultimately boring after some time.
Probably the most competitive and highest skill ceiling fighting game out there. Should be the main attraction at evo and other fgc events.
The one true fighting game.
Focus on the zen of diving and kicking.
In my first match i played as a fat man who took down a furry 10/10
Great game to play drunk with friends.
Focus on the zen of diving and kicking.
For a parody game, it seems to have distilled both the twitch and the mind-games of the fighting game genre. Worth $5.
This review should only need 2 words, but i'm hipster.  DIVE.KICK.
I fear not the man who has practiced ten-thousand kicks once, but I fear the man who had practiced one kick ten-thousand times.
EDIT: Yun and Yang the game
a meme that got way toof ucking meta
SHARK TALLLLLEEEEEEEE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
This game is the ♥♥♥♥!
awesome game - easy game - worth to buy   once you got it , let's play together .     ---

Played this for my first time at PAX East against the Evo Champion. I figured with two buttons, maybe I could get in a single lucky win on him. Not a chance, this game takes way more skill then you'd think, and is a ton of fun.

I am not a fighting game player.   That being said Divekick is the best fighting game I have ever played. Sure I really liked stuff like Street Fighter, Mortal Kombat, and the like... But Divekick is the first time I ever felt like I could compete legitimately.   The Lang Zone is in full effect here with a brilliantly minimalist design. All characters have a million health and every attack does four million damage. There are two buttons. You jump, and then you kick. The brilliance of this design is that it is so simple yet there is depth in the way each character jumps, how each one kicks, and how their supers behave. Even the super moves are brilliantly simple, being activated simply by hitting both buttons at once and changing depending on whether you are on the ground or in the air.  I watched this game developed from the ground up thanks to the beautiful romance between Dave Lang and the GB crew and I'm so happy I saw it all the way through. I might not play it nearly as much as I should but if you want a fun, fast, popcorn-like fighting game nothing does it better than Divekick.  Get bopped, son.

This is what you call a fighting game! No overly complex combos to memorize in order to have the most fune in this game! Anyone, young or old can play it and be good at it! Plus, all the characters have little attributes unique to them so the game doesn't get stale, as it only uses two buttons. BUY THIS NOW.
Best game about Diving AND Kicking I have ever played.
Want to kick a mutated honeybader in the face? In this game you can!

Easy to learn, difficult to master. Every round is essentially down to the wire (1-hit kills) which makes for an intense experience. 'Dive' to jump straight up and 'Kick' to kick in a preset angle afterward (Kick can also let you jump backwards). Each character has their own preset Kick angle and special moves.  Unfortunately, the game was a victim of its own hype, it took too long to come out. It's littered with a ton of 'Fighting Game Community' inside jokes. The character designs leave much to be desired.  Still an enjoyable experience, but non-fighting gamers may not like the concept.
Bought it for stupid fun, stayed for the Engrish.

The problem with most parodies is that they get so caught up in hilighting what makes something bad that the parody often isn't fun to play.  Dive kick doesn't make that mistake. It's a fun game that says something about fighters without being painful to play. and yes, there really are only 2 buttons, even for the menu. Not as technical as a 'real' fighting games, but there's something for people of all skill levels to enjoy here.
This game is so dumb that it's fun.

HEY! DO YOU LIKE DIVING? DO YOU LIKE KICKING? Then maybe this is the game for you. If you have always wanted to get into fighting games and learn the mind games but struggle with things like 'combos' and 'counters', get this game. It's a nice introduction to fighting games, while including quite a bit of depth you wouldn't expect from watching a few games. Try it out!!!
Best fighting game in the history of ever. Never played a game so simple with such a high skill cap.
Great game Great experience
This game is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. The skill involved, the complicated game mechanics, the thought behind it. This is like sex. Without the need of condoms. Please, buy this game, it's the best right now.
this game has everything you need its got dives its got kicks and more importantly it has THE BAZ!
BEST GAME EVAR!  really tho if you dont play this game you are a next level ♥♥♥♥♥.

At first glance, the game seems like a complete joke and in some ways it is. Hidden under the comedic side of the game is some actual solid gameplay mechanics. Instead of having to master massive combos and 1 frame links this game gets you right into the action with a very easy to learn and simple control scheme. Even with its low skill requirement for entry level play the game still maintains a very high skill ceiling.   The game essentially takes out a lot of the memorization and muscle memory required to play a fighter and all that remains is the core to what makes every fighting game so great, the skill and tactics required to defeat your opponent.  If you're interested in a fighting game that's all about positioning, reflexes, and mind games then Divekick is for you.

All the shenanigans of a fighting game, without spending hours in training mode learning your character. If you are looking for a simple fighting game that is easy to get into yet has most, maybe all, of the fighting game core 'values' then this is your game.

Divekick is an exellent distillation of fighting games. It demonstrates the reason why fighting games can be so interesting while somehow still managing to be accessible enough to be a great game to just take and show friends who aren't in to fighting games. I definitely reccomend it to anyone who's looking for a fun game and enjoys local multiplayer situations.
Would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys games that get extremely boring and repetitive after the first hour or so of playing.
This is the greatest, most intense, most hype fighting game in all time.
Mr. N OP and it has Goku
You Dive and You Kick. It is a pretty fun game but don't expect to be spending hours upon hours playing this game, its a fun game to play for a few minutes or against friends.
I'VE NEVER BEEN SO SALTY IN MY ENTIRE LIFE!!!!

Easy to learn, difficult to master. Every round is essentially down to the wire (1-hit kills) which makes for an intense experience. 'Dive' to jump straight up and 'Kick' to kick in a preset angle afterward (Kick can also let you jump backwards). Each character has their own preset Kick angle and special moves.  Unfortunately, the game was a victim of its own hype, it took too long to come out. It's littered with a ton of 'Fighting Game Community' inside jokes. The character designs leave much to be desired.  Still an enjoyable experience, but non-fighting gamers may not like the concept.
You have only 2 fingers? No problem! This game for you! JK :) Awesome game
The most confusing, and possibly most short lived, yet enjoyable fighting game I've ever played

Divekick boils all of fighting games down to a very simple set of rules, and it does them well. If you want something fiercely competitive but approachable, get this. Also, if you don't like 2D fighting games, and you're not sure why, this might help. Control, priority, spacing and footsies are all represented in some way in this game, and if you're a button masher at heart, this game can actually help you out of your awful habits. The number of fighting game community injokes and silliness is a bit bewildering for those outside of the community, however. Just smile and nod if you feel like there's supposed to be a joke there.
You dive, you kick and fun times are had by all.
The single greatest fighting game. Requires a lot more planning than one would expect :P

At first glance, the game seems like a complete joke and in some ways it is. Hidden under the comedic side of the game is some actual solid gameplay mechanics. Instead of having to master massive combos and 1 frame links this game gets you right into the action with a very easy to learn and simple control scheme. Even with its low skill requirement for entry level play the game still maintains a very high skill ceiling.   The game essentially takes out a lot of the memorization and muscle memory required to play a fighter and all that remains is the core to what makes every fighting game so great, the skill and tactics required to defeat your opponent.  If you're interested in a fighting game that's all about positioning, reflexes, and mind games then Divekick is for you.
This game Dived onto my soul, then Kicked its way into my heart <3

ENTER THE LANG ZONE. Simple enough to pick up and have fun with, nuanced enough that it seems to have a decent skill cap, especially after balancing. The game really commits to the two button setup, and though visually it may be kind of bland, it is still a pretty good time. Worth the full $10, though it seems to go on sale relatively often. 7.5/10
A two button fighter that will either make you feel like a strategic badass or a total chump. Everything is fighting game reference and this crap gets really dumb really fast. 10/10 would dive again

At first glance, the game seems like a complete joke and in some ways it is. Hidden under the comedic side of the game is some actual solid gameplay mechanics. Instead of having to master massive combos and 1 frame links this game gets you right into the action with a very easy to learn and simple control scheme. Even with its low skill requirement for entry level play the game still maintains a very high skill ceiling.   The game essentially takes out a lot of the memorization and muscle memory required to play a fighter and all that remains is the core to what makes every fighting game so great, the skill and tactics required to defeat your opponent.  If you're interested in a fighting game that's all about positioning, reflexes, and mind games then Divekick is for you.
buy it it has wil smif
A great, easy to pick up game with all the action of a more complicated fighter.

Divekick is a new take at the fighting genre. Designed with the intention of making fighting game less completed.Divekick introduces us to a two button scheme. One must simply jump and dive to knock out the opposing player this often leads to players diving back and forth with tension skyrocketing as they wonder who will be hit first. in addition the games divekicks each character has a air and ground ability which can change the tide of many a battle allowing new trickery and backstabbing. With a wide host of characters each with their own campagn. One can easily find hours of enjoyment out of mastering each one before inviting friends to crush or before trying out the ranked online. However divekick still has its flaws there is no way to back out of character select screens at all unless you join a game. Another error is two people may divekick each at the same time and be hit with a double ko or only one will be. This happens whenever it feels like and often make it confusing to guess one someone is going to be ko. all in all Divekick is a good game with flaws but nothing gamebreaking or unplayable. Grab your friends and find out who is a fraud or be choked out.

Need a fighting game to play with some d00ds but dont want to learn all of those pesky combos and motions? Grab this game! All you need are two buttons! THAT'S RIGHT...2! @! TWO! Plus what's not fun about Diving and Kicking? Hey d00d what you doing over there? Aww nothing much man, I'm just diving and kicking!

Dive! Kick! It's all in the mind, If you wanna test me, I'm sure you'll find, That all the things I'll teach ya, is sure to beat ya, But nevertheless you'll get a lesson from teacher,  Now Kick - Dive - Dive - Kick Once more now, Kick - Dive - Dive - And Kick

reasons why this is the best fighting game:  it does not have the bad and unfun mechanic known as 'blocking' and 'skill'   you can choose to be good at this game, and you CAN get good, but you can also choose to be bad. and you will have fun and win either way.
DIVAH KIKUAH!!!!!!!!!!!!! Best two button game ever made.. Ever.
get this game everrett is bad and the baz too great
The best game that i have ever played
Do you like to dive? Do you like to kick? These questions are irrelevant because this is a video game and you cant actually get the same experience as doing those things from this game.
The HYPEST game ever created. Emulates that down-to-the minute gameplay of every fighter. Surprisingly deep gameplay mechanics for a literal two-button system.
its fun while is lasts. ...approx 30min. this game is funny, but this aint worth full price. wait for summer sale or autumn sale or...yeah. just wait.
My personal favorite fighting game. 10/10

Take all fighting games with their complexity, all the combos, blocks counters frame whatevers. This game manages to be that complex but by being simple. You have two moves. Dive (jump) and kick (kick) and with that comes all the nuance. It takes one hit to kill your oppponent. This game manages to lampoon fighting games and in itself becomes the most simple and easily understood fighting game.

Simple yet complex. Delightful and humorous in small spurts. Highly recommended at sale price but you could probably spend $10 dollars in better ways. Still if your lookin' for a good party game, this is it!
It's an awesome fighting game and it's extremely accessible. Worth it, specially if the thing that turns you off of fighting games is doing the motions.
Solid game to pickup on sale. Yes it's kind of a novelty, but it's great with a friend to play agasint.

Divekick is a silly game. A good kind of silly, you can sit down for half an hour against a friend, either locally or online and have a fun time. The fun comes out of the unpredictable nature of the game, who will win the next round? A fun game if it is cheap but you won't play it for long, if a friend has it, challenge them online, much more fun.
Dumb Simple Funny KICK
....??? i dont know how but yeah...
Fighting game with only two buttons. Jump and kick.
So much fun with friends. Plug in a couple of controllers and have a blast.

Great party game for casuals and hardcore fighting game veterans alike. There's so much metagame, you could make a spinoff about it. Add in a cast of characters with their own inside jokes, different dive/kicking styles, FGC humor, and you have a simple, yet complex game that laughs at what a genre has become over the years.   But seriously, make sure you have people to play this with.   2/10 - Solo 8/10 - With friends

This game is absolutely astounding. The simplicity of the gameplay but the depth of the special moves, added to the sheer amount of hype generated with every round, Divekick is great for parties and occasional boot ups when bored.

It's an alright game, very easy controls (you only use two buttons really.), can be a bit of a challenge at first.   Sadly the online part of this game seems to be 100% dead though, as I sat for a very long time in queue with nothing occuring both in ranked and unranked, and not finding lobby rooms in public or private.  If that doesn't bother you It can be rather fun.

Great party game for casuals and hardcore fighting game veterans alike. There's so much metagame, you could make a spinoff about it. Add in a cast of characters with their own inside jokes, different dive/kicking styles, FGC humor, and you have a simple, yet complex game that laughs at what a genre has become over the years.   But seriously, make sure you have people to play this with.   2/10 - Solo 8/10 - With friends
A game of quirky and competitive matches that is best enjoyed with friends in the same room. You'd never guess that such simple controls can lead to such tactical gameplay.
2 buttons, various characters with unique styles, fun party game to have to the collection.
You dive, or you kick, there is no in between! A fighting game boiled down to the most satisfying action you'll play in this dimension;great fun in local co-op!
I just love to Dive and then Kick!
Might as well call this game Super MemeFighter: FGC Parady edition. It's good for a quick laugh if you keep up with the FGC, but it's a gimmick that wears off quickly.
Blows ♥♥♥

Do I recommend this ? Yes, but but only if you like to buy jokes. Real jokes. Funny jokes. I'm serious here, this game is a genuine joke. If you cant take it, buy it and laugh. Plus it's a cheap laugh!  If you want an actual game, DON'T BUY THIS ONE. I do not recommend this GAME. What I do recommend is watching the videos, trailers and all the content around. It's part of the joke, and it's a good one.

Fighting games live or die by their communities, and Divekick's is as dead as it gets. Saturday morning, I sit here trying Unranked and Ranked, and getting zero matches. The story mode is shallow enough that you'll quickly get tired of it, and there's just nothing else here to spend your time on.  Despite its simplicity and questionable character balance, Divekick would be a great game to pick up and play in short bursts, like a snack... but there's simply no action going on to participate in.
4,99€ is already 4,99€ too much for this game.

what a pile of ♥♥♥♥. It started off being a joke, but some stubborn gamers decided to keep going with it to avoid looking like idiots. Quite easily the stupidest game I think I've ever played. People who love this game will show you this review and suggest that I don't 'get' it. There's nothing to get. This is nothing more than a glorified flash game.

I don't hate it, it's fun for a short while but it gets boring and repetetive really quickly. If you want a simple fighting game then get this, but if you want something with depth and complexity look somewhere else.
Couldn't force myself to play very much of this game. Interesting idea, but it felt like something from Newgrounds. Very shallow.
Too Simple. Feels like a joke for the 2D Fighter scene.

Sometimes you find a really bad game. Sometimes you find a decent game with terrible humor, dialouge, characters, art design, and direction. Unless you were on the development team for this game you won't get 99% of the 'jokes'. Like what the hell is with [REDACTED]? What about Kenny? The only theory I have for Kenny is that he's a member of the dev team that died during development. The art is cartoony, but being cartoony isn't a 'Get Out of Jail Free' card. The lines are rough, the designs are somewhere between Eastern and Western and this just messes you up. The dialouge is ♥♥♥♥ing ridiculous and again, the jokes fall so flat you'd expect James Cameron to come down in a submarine and look at them.

I don't even know why I'm writing this. Even my grandmother knows what Divekick is, and if you're reading this, you've already seen a couple screens of it and probably skimmed a couple other reviews.  I organize my steam library by genre, and when I went to sort this one, it gave me pause. Sure, it's kind of a fighting game, but it's also a bit of a strategy. Mostly, it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.   The worlds first two-button fighter (and it means that literally. No analog stick movement at all. Dive. Kick.) comes to us from Iron Galaxy games, and maybe it should have stayed there. Previously a developer for Dungeons and Dragons digital titles, they moved to a heavily meme-inflated 'fighting' game where you first dive (or 'jump', but whatever) by pressing one button, and then, while in the air, kick using the other. That's it. There's a cast of characters to choose from, most of them harkening back to inside jokes.   It's moderately funny, I guess, but that's hardly a reason to spend 10 bucks. Basically if you have Divekick, it's because you got hyped on it (or in my case, someone gifted it) and spent maybe as long as I have playing it. Poor replay value outside of sheer novelty, poor gameplay attibuting victories to luck rather than any variant of skill, and after the third or fourth time he holds up the, 'I don't hug white girls.' sign, the joke loses its luster, and I quit out to go play a fighting game with more than two buttons.   Should you get it? Do you make enough money to literally waste ten dollars? Sure, but if you're even a tiny bit iffy about it, wait until the next time it's 90% off. In the meantime, there are better ten dollar games.  Hell, there are better FIVE dollar games. Get two.
WTF did I just bought?
feels unfinished
PUTTING A SHOE ON YOUR HAND AND DIVING IS NOT A DIVEKICK! IMMERSION RUINED PLZ FIX DEVS

I like the idea of this game and the concept seemed to be solid through my play-throughs of the single player but it really doesn't hold up for long as an only single player game. That became pretty problematic when I realized that the online multiplayer scene was utterly dead when I played it. Maybe if you have people to play with locally you would have better luck with it?
The novelty wears off quick.

It is a good game with some interesting mechanics and it is enjoyable if you are going to play it with your friends locally and only for short periods of time.  But if you think about playing online or ranked this game is the worse, beside it being old and it is empty like the sahara desert. when you are lucky (NOT) to find a match their online system is crap it is unplayable from how bad it manges higher ping.
